title: Is this the world’s murder capital?
text:
What are these? Violence surges ... Police members detain a suspected gang member in El Salvador. Source: AP 
AUSTRALIAN travellers are urged to think twice about visiting El Salvador as the country’s bloodshed spirals to terrifying new heights amid a resurgence in gang violence. 
The South American nation, which sits near Guatemala, Honduras and Nicaragua, was last month ravaged by 677 murders — more than any other single month since the country’s civil war ended in 1992. 
The average kills per day amounted to 22.6 
El Salvador’s Legal Medicine Institute director Miguel Fortin Magana said June’s total surpassed May’s 641 murders, in an alarming indication of the growing carnage residents are facing. 
The first six months of this year have resulted in 2965 murders. In the same period last year, there were 1840 — astonishing numbers for a country with a population of just 6.1 million. High-intensity ... Police units speed to respond to an emergency call. Source: AP 
The violence has skyrocketed as street gangs renewed clashes between themselves and with government forces. 
ON THE BRINK: Women in El Salvador face up to 40 years jail if they have an abortion 
A gang truce which lasted for more than a year saw the average daily murders fall to about six, but this broke down in January. 
During El Salvador’s bloody 12-year civil war, an estimated 76,000 people died and an additional 12,000 disappeared. Hitting home ... Relatives of a gang member who was shot dead retrieve his body from gully. Source: AP 
Closer to home, figures from the Australian Bureau of Statistics meanwhile show Australia’s murder rates are dropping, with 249 in 2013 down from 254 the previous year. 
South America is a growing hotspot for Australian globe-trotters with its promise of spectacular historic attractions, colourful parties, Amazonian adventures and pristine beaches. 
But on the federal government’s Smart Traveller website , Australian tourists are urged to “exercise a high degree of caution” when heading to El Salvador “because of high levels of violent crime”. 
“Pay close attention to your personal security at all times and monitor the media for information about possible new safety or security risks,” the website warns in its May 25 update. 
“Violent crime is common and widespread in El Salvador, including in the capital San Salvador. “Violent crime in El Salvador often involves firearms.” The thick of it ... Police patrol a rural area after a violent fight. Source: AP Tragic find ... Police find a severely injured man they believe may have been tortured and dumped. Source: AP With more than 60 murders per 100,000 citizens, El Salvador is one of the most violent nations in the world.
Police officials have blamed the worsening insecurity on the breakdown of a truce made between the gangs and the government in 2013. 
While the homicide rate plunged during the truce, it is believed it gave gangs time to strengthen and acquire more brutal weapons. 
Gang leaders are in maximum-security cells, but the streets are now controlled by younger, reckless criminals.
